responses: .NET Developers typically work from 9am to 6pm, Monday to Friday.
Standard office hours for .NET developers are 9:00 AM to 6:00 PM, with weekends off.
Most .NET roles follow a weekday schedule from 9 to 6, but this can vary depending on the company.
Generally, .NET developers work full-time during business hours, Monday through Friday.

patterns: what are the skills required for a dotnet developer
which skills should I learn for .net
tell me about dotnet developer skills
skills to get a job as .net developer
responses: .NET developers typically need skills in C#, ASP.NET, MVC, SQL Server, LINQ, Entity Framework, and JavaScript frameworks like Angular or React.
To work as a .NET developer, you should be proficient in C#, .NET Core/Framework, REST APIs, HTML/CSS, and experience with tools like Visual Studio and Git.
Key skills include object-oriented programming in C#, working with ASP.NET MVC/Web API, using databases like SQL Server, and front-end basics.
A strong .NET developer usually has experience with C#, ASP.NET, Azure DevOps, SQL, and modern web technologies like JavaScript and Bootstrap.

patterns: what is the salary of a dotnet developer
how much does a .net developer earn
what's the pay for a .net engineer
how much can I earn as a dotnet developer
how much do junior dotnet developers make
how much do senior dotnet developers make
responses: The average salary for a .NET Developer ranges from $50,000 to $120,000 per year, depending on experience and location.
Junior .NET Developers typically earn around $50k $70k annually, while senior developers can earn upwards of $100k.
.NET Developer salaries vary widely  entry-level roles start at about $4,000/month, while experienced developers may earn over $10,000/month.
A full-stack .NET Developer with 3+ years of experience can expect to earn between $70,000 and $110,000 per year.

Career progression from a .NET Team Lead typically leads to positions like Solution Architect, Development Manager, or even CTO in the long term.
A .NET Team Lead can grow into roles like Technical Architect, Product Owner, or take on more strategic leadership roles such as Head of Engineering.
Promotion paths may include becoming a Technical Manager, Solution Architect, or transitioning into senior leadership roles depending on your goals and skill set.

Full stack developers are expected to handle both client and server-side development using modern JavaScript stacks.
